[confidently] But, um, that's just it!

[hesitantly] Look, I understand you're passionate about this, [sarcastic], but passion doesn't make something scientifically viable or, [formal], eligible for patent protection under current regulations. [sigh]

[clearing throat]
[curious] Have you ever wondered though, what if one of those rejected inventions, [passionate], could have actually changed the world if you'd just given it a chance?

[confused] I shouldn't be saying this, but your persistence, [trailing off], it reminds me of why I became a patent examiner in the first place...
[quickly] To help bring meaningful innovations into the world, to be part of something, [sleepily], no wait I'm getting ahead of myself—to witness the moment when, [gasp], an idea becomes reality?

[cough] Well, um, perhaps we should review your improvements one more time, and I mean, [very quietly], really examine them with fresh eyes this time, er, without my usual skepticism getting in the way.

[friendly] I'm saying that, um, sometimes optimism is contagious, and maybe, [playful], just maybe this office needs a device that measures happiness more than, [sniffle], I care to admit, you know? [gasp softly]

[delighted] This is exactly what I've been trying to explain—that hope isn't naive, [very excited], it's necessary for innovation, and sometimes all it takes is, [loudly], one person willing to believe!

[thoughtful] Well then, let's, er, schedule a formal review for next week, and, [sincerely], bring all your documentation because if we're going to do this, [whispering loudly], we're going to do it right, hmm, even if it means challenging the entire patent system's approach to abstract concepts. [groan]
